The tenor sings: and when eight days were over, the child was to be circumcised and he was given the name Jesus.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Sylvia Poggioli, NPR News, Berlin.
We're hearing some worrying economic news from a number of We're hearing some worrying economic news from a number of places this week.
Industrial production in the 16 countries that use the euro fell unexpectedly in June, after rising for several months.
Stock prices are falling.
In fact, markets in the U.S.
and abroad had one of their worst days in weeks, just yesterday.
That is partly because of a series of disappointing reports that are leaving many economists pessimistic.
Here's NPR's Jim Zarroli.
Economists have been saying, for nearly a year, that the recession is over.
But these days, they're sounding a little less confident about what may happen over the next few months.
Two surveys released this week, by Bloomberg and Marketwatch, indicate that economists are lowering their growth projections for the second half of 2010.
Bloomberg said the median forecast has fallen from 2.8 percent to a little more than 2 and a half percent.
It was 3.7 percent during the first three months of this year.
Nariman Behravesh, of IHS Global insight, says weak demand will hurt the economy between now and the end of the year.
We have what might be called an epidemic of thrift - which is to say, consumers are saving a lot, businesses are saving a lot; they're being very careful about their spending.
He says the weak job market is hurting demand, and a lot of businesses are reluctant to invest and hire.
Behravesh says the surge in imports, reported by the government yesterday, has lowered growth.
It does mean that more of our growth in demand went overseas, so it's not going to help the economy very much.
Most economists still believe the odds of a double-dip recession are slim and that growth will continue, but it will be tepid until next year - when it should pick up somewhat.
Jim Zarroli, NPR News, New York.
(Soundbite of music)
Venezuela's president has taken control of some of its country's biggest industries since taking power a decade ago, and now Hugo Chavez wants to take over golf courses.
He says the sport is elitist and he's taken steps that could turn golf courses into public parks.
NPR's Juan Forero takes us to the decidedly elite Caracas Country Club.
In this chaotic city, the 18-hole Caracas Country Club is an oasis.
Trees line the course on the east and west, and the lush towering Avila mountain range looms to the north.
(Soundbite of ball teeing off)
It's the perfect escape for Pasqual Sesiena(ph), who tees off on a recent sunny morning.
He plays here every day and he says he doesn't take it for granted.
You can get in a round of golf just about every day, so I mean, it's real nice.
It's - that's probably why he wants to take it away.
By he, Sesiena means populist President Hugo Chavez.
On his TV show, Chavez didn't rail against this course, but he did take on golf.
(Spanish spoken)
Chavez said golf was a bourgeois sport.
(Spanish spoken)
He also mocked golfers for using carts, saying they were lazy.
And he said that having a golf course in the middle of a city cannot be justified.
Golf courses, Chavez said, take up valuable land that could be used for housing.
(Soundbite of automobile)
Caracas is a city of interminable traffic jams, garbage-strewn streets and sprawling slums.
Green space comes at a premium.
Mr. RAPHAEL CARRAETO(ph) (Carpenter): (Spanish spoken)
And that was when I was seeing Tina Turner.
That was really an unusual time for me.
They start at the same time.
It's like the sculpture in the rock, you have to chip away and it and just, you know, not think too much and just keep going.
A song like ""Burgundy Shoes"" to me is like a perfect little film, tiny little film.
And I imagine that it comes from some very vivid memory maybe you had of being a little girl, but, you know, maybe just the process you're describing sounds very far from that.
I was challenged from a friend of mine to write a happier song, so I just literally sat at the piano and trying to not write a sad song.
(Soundbite of song, ""Burgundy Shoes"")
(Singing) We wait for the bus that's going to Bangor in my plaid dress and burgundy shoes.
In your red lipstick and lilac kerchief, you were the most pretty lady in the world.
I went back to happy memory and that's one my first ones is hanging with mom, waiting for the bus, going to - I grew up in Old Town, Maine.
If you take the bus to Bangor, that was the big city.
And just those little buses with the vinyl seats.
(Soundbite of song, ""Burgundy Shoes"")
(Singing) We climb on our seats.
The vinyl is cold.
Michelle, Ma Belle - the song that you loved then.
You hold my hand and sing to yourself in the sun, in the sun, sun, sun, sun, sun.
When you're little, first of all, everybody smiles at you because you're cute, so you think the world is great.
And everything is so vivid.
You know, you're not clouded out by anxiety and you don't miss things.
You see the sun and you see your mom's lipstick and how beautiful she is.
You know, you just don't miss anything when you're four years old or three years old.
There's a line - it's the first day I don't wear my big boots.
Yeah.
That was always a really big deal growing up in Maine.
You know, you had to put those red rubber boots on over your lovely shoes, you know.
And I really was frustrated by those red rubber boots, so when they - when we were finally allowed to take them off, it was a pretty exciting day.
(Soundbite of song, ""Burgundy Shoes"")
(Singing) The leaves are green and new like a baby.
Tulips are red.
No, I don't miss the snow.
It's the first day I don't wear my big boots.
You hold my hand.
I've got burgundy shoes.
Burgundy shoes.
Burgundy shoes on.
You've been recording for, I guess, about 10 years.
Do you think your voice has changed?
Yeah, it has.
It's getting a little huskier, I think.
And I was given some old, old, old recordings from like the late '80s and early '90s from somebody last year, and I have lost some of that high bell sweetness, and that's probably gone for good.
Emilou Harris sings on this record and she's got this amazing thing happening to her voice.
Now she's coming up on 60 if she's been there already, and you just don't here a lot of those voices being recorded anymore.
I mean, it's strange, but there is some much in her voice because of all of the years she's been singing and all the experience she has had in her life.
And it has a soul to it that is rare and, you know, we were all in tears, you know, when she was putting her parts down.
(Soundbite of song, ""Trapeze"")
(Singing) She started with us on the back of a horse, just 17 and already divorced.
She took the air the greatest of ease, like she was born to be gliding on the old trapeze.
This is the song ""Trapeze."" Tell me about the song and how it started.
Well, I turned 48 a couple of years ago, and if there's something about doing what I do for a living, it's you start getting the brush off.
I mean, a lot of women entertainers, actors, musicians talk about it and - but I do think it's all in your head.
You know what I mean?
You can accept that perception of yourself that you're getting too old to be interesting or buyable.
Or you can kind of do what you do and see what happens.
